channel.title: Comments on: The Productive DBA: Part 2 Document the Database
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: ptheriault
item.dc:creator: ptheriault
item.description: @jrara, Yes, and I've updated a few tables that way. It is much safer than using SSMS, because there is less chance to modify something else. But, Like SSMS it can be very time consuming on a db with a lot of objects. I'm a huge fan of SQL Doc and the documentation that is generated by the tool. It's very clean and saves tons of time trying to create that level of documentation manualy.
item.content:encoded: @jrara, Yes, and I’ve updated a few tables that way. It is much safer than using SSMS, because there is less chance to modify something else. But, Like SSMS it can be very time consuming on a db with a lot of objects. I’m a huge fan of SQL Doc and the documentation that is generated by the tool. It’s very clean and saves tons of time trying to create that level of documentation manualy.

item.title: By: jrara
item.dc:creator: jrara
item.description: You can also use Red Gate's SQL Doc to add entended properties to table columns.
item.content:encoded: You can also use Red Gate’s SQL Doc to add entended properties to table columns.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
How many times have you started at a new company or been given a new database that you have to code for and you have no clue how the schema relates

Every time
